stream_context.summary: Kaze does a bonus dev stream focused on two things: (1) pausing the in-progress Western/Wild West level to create missing mission (star) names and an intro cutscene for Oily Boily Bay, syncing camera cuts to the level music using spline-based camera paths; (2) returning to the Western level’s “surreal canyon” sub-area design, adding landmark set pieces and implementing differently colored warp pipes as optional shortcuts, including debugging a crash caused by new pipe-color code.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains practical production details (cutscene workflow, mission naming, warp-pipe shortcut design), clear constraints (64MB cartridge, free/open-source release), and a concrete debugging incident (pipe color geo code causing a crash) that reveals Kaze’s technical process and tooling.

findings.summary: Kaze’s Western level plan includes a small town hub (milk bar, sheriff office/jail, bank, train, windmills/tumbleweeds) plus a second, more surreal canyon area filled with oversized symbolic Western props (giant shotgun, skull, wheel, horseshoe/hoof iron) used for movement-focused platforming and a scavenger-hunt style star.

The scavenger-hunt star concept: an NPC gives an initial hint (e.g., “inside the big skull”), the player ground-pounds at landmarks to reveal the next clue via signs, chaining clues that send the player across the canyon landmarks and platforming routes to ultimately find a treasure.

Warp pipes in the Western canyon area are positioned as optional shortcuts between sub-areas (e.g., wheel area, Yoshi ranch area, end-of-area), intended to add discovery and routing rather than being required traversal; Kaze rejects adding excessive on-screen text labels, preferring a “sleek design” that doesn’t over-explain.
findings.quote: The worst thing that happens when you enter a pipe you didn’t mean to is that you have to enter the pipe again—it’s going to take like five seconds out of your life.

findings.summary: Kaze is actively iterating level naming and mission naming for clarity and player guidance; he emphasizes that mission names should hint at the objective (e.g., referencing the crane/cannon in Oily Boily Bay) rather than being purely vibes-based or cryptic.

He stops Western-level work mid-stream to finish overdue production tasks for Oily Boily Bay: defining star/mission names and creating the intro cutscene so it’s no longer blocked by missing presentation elements.

Oily Boily Bay intro cutscene implementation uses multiple camera spline segments (“three cutscene splines”) and Kaze tunes cut timing by frames to land cuts on musical beats; he considers beat alignment the top priority for the cutscene’s feel.
findings.quote: The most important part of the cutscene for me is that it’s fitting to the music.

findings.summary: Biobak is expected to finish at least one unfinished Oily Boily Bay section (a power-generator/platforming area) and other polish tasks (collision and remaining area completion), indicating parallelized level completion where Kaze integrates others’ content.
Zeina is working on a large skull asset for the Western canyon area (a key landmark used in the scavenger-hunt clue chain).

Badub is confirmed as the level music composer for Kaze’s levels “nowadays,” and Kaze listens to level music while doing mission naming/cutscene timing, implying music is integrated early enough to drive pacing decisions.
Kaze uses the Blender → SM64 pipeline via Fast64 (Blender plugin) to import models directly into the N64-compatible format, reinforcing that the art workflow is tightly coupled to decomp tools.

Colored warp pipes required per-instance color control; Kaze chooses a geo-layout approach (a custom GeoASM/geo node to set pipe color from behavior parameters) rather than making the pipe material two-cycle, which he considers undesirable for performance/quality tradeoffs.

Adding the colored warp pipes initially caused a crash; Kaze avoided heavy debugging until necessary, then used NEMU64 (preferred over PJ64 Debugger) to obtain the exact program counter and traced the crash into his “geo set pipe color” code, enabling a targeted fix.

Kaze reiterates a hard packaging constraint: the full game should fit on a standard N64 cartridge size (he targets ≤64MB and frames going beyond as potentially ‘cheating’ even if larger carts are technically possible).
findings.quote: It is one of my conditions that it fits on a normal N64 cartridge. I’m not gonna go above 64 megabytes.

findings.summary: He states the project will be open source and cannot be monetized directly due to Nintendo risk, framing release strategy as ‘free or else.’
findings.quote: I unfortunately cannot monetize this. I have to release it for free or I will get murdered.

findings.summary: Kaze mentions practical payment friction with Biobak: PayPal is not currently usable, pushing them toward crypto payments with fees and tax complications—an example of real-world operations affecting production.

biobak.summary: Kaze notes the Oily Boily Bay power-generator/platforming area is unfinished and says Biobak would finish it; Kaze also mentions remaining needs like collision and a song for that section.
Kaze says he wants to pay Biobak with “paper money,” but can’t use PayPal right now, forcing crypto with extra fees on both sides and tax headaches.

badub.summary: Kaze identifies Badub as the composer for the level music (and says Badub makes the music for his levels “nowadays”).

zeina.summary: Zeina is actively producing a large skull asset for the Western level’s canyon area, which will be both a set piece and part of the scavenger-hunt clue path.

findings.summary: Lilaa gives feedback on aesthetics (pipes) and prompts discussion about readability/accessibility (color differentiation), which Kaze considers but ultimately resolves by choosing distinct colors and downplaying the cost of a wrong pipe choice.
Kaze references using/borrowing PowerJay’s pipe texture/model resources when his own textures/assets are missing or inconsistent, suggesting asset-sharing within the ROMhack/dev community.

memorable_quotes.context: Kaze explains a broader design philosophy inspired by playing SpongeBob: Battle for Bikini Bottom, arguing that modern games often fail at basic player-respect and that low-friction design can be a winning formula.

key_stories.title: Interrupting level building to finish Oily Boily Bay’s missing presentation layer
key_stories.summary: While working on the Western level, Kaze realizes Oily Boily Bay still lacks finalized mission names and an intro cutscene. He pauses Western progress to complete these tasks, treating them as necessary polish and player-facing guidance.
key_stories.challenge: Oily Boily Bay’s star naming and intro cutscene weren’t done, risking unclear objectives and incomplete level presentation.
key_stories.process: Kaze drafts mission names with an emphasis on hinting objectives (especially the crane/cannon) and then builds a three-part camera-spline intro cutscene, adjusting frame timing so cuts align with the music’s beat changes.
key_stories.outcome: He’s satisfied enough with the beat-synced result to mark the task complete and return to the Western level.
key_stories.key_quote: The most important part of the cutscene for me is that it’s fitting to the music.

key_stories.title: Designing the Western canyon area around movement, landmarks, and a clue chain
key_stories.summary: Kaze outlines a second Western area that’s intentionally surreal: canyons filled with giant symbolic props. A scavenger-hunt mission uses an NPC hint plus sign-based clues discovered by ground-pounding at landmarks to route the player through platforming.
key_stories.challenge: Make a large traversal space fun without overcomplicating it or relying on heavy scripting everywhere.
key_stories.process: He blocks out the space with placeholder geometry, plans major props (shotgun walkable set piece, skull, wheel, hoof iron, shed), and designs a multi-step clue chain that sends the player between landmarks; he considers adding warp-pipe shortcuts to increase discovery and routing variety.
key_stories.outcome: By stream end, the area is “roughly mapped out,” with next steps being adding set pieces, implementing the scavenger mission, and potentially completing the first star quickly once props and logic are in place.

key_stories.title: Colored warp pipes: feature implementation turns into a crash hunt
key_stories.summary: To support shortcut routing, Kaze implements multiple pipe colors so players can match entrances/exits. Immediately, the game starts crashing when entering pipes, prompting deeper debugging than he prefers to do mid-flow.
key_stories.challenge: A newly added pipe-color system caused crashes with no obvious cause in the high-level setup.
key_stories.process: Kaze implements color via geo-layout/GeoASM driven by behavior parameters, avoids launching full debugger until forced, then uses NEMU64 to get the crash PC and traces it into his custom “geo set pipe color” routine.
key_stories.outcome: He identifies the crash location (his code) and proceeds toward a fix, validating his workflow of using emulation/debug tools only when necessary and favoring NEMU64 for actionable crash addresses.

key_stories.title: Paying an artist becomes a production problem
key_stories.summary: Kaze mentions he can’t currently pay Biobak via PayPal and is pushed toward crypto transfers. He’s frustrated by fees on both sides and tax/accounting complications, calling it an unnecessary obstacle.
key_stories.challenge: Tooling/payment restrictions interfere with routine team compensation.
key_stories.process: Kaze considers alternatives (prefers bank transfer/“paper money”), but notes current constraints; the issue remains unresolved within the stream.
key_stories.outcome: Payment friction remains a background production risk and potential morale/logistics issue for ongoing collaboration.

open_questions.topic: Oily Boily Bay mission list and final naming rules
open_questions.context: Kaze drafts/edits mission names live, aiming for names that hint objectives (crane/cannon/strike/boss/8-bit pipe), and notes some names are placeholders that may change.
questions: What is the finalized star/mission list for Oily Boily Bay, and which names changed after this stream?
How do you decide the balance between ‘vibes’ names vs. explicit hinting names across the whole game?
Do you playtest mission-name clarity with fresh players, or rely on internal judgement?

open_questions.topic: Intro cutscene toolchain and data format
open_questions.context: Kaze builds the intro cutscene from multiple camera splines and tunes timings by frames to match music beats.
questions: What tools/scripts do you use to author and preview camera splines (in-engine vs external)?
How is the cutscene stored in the codebase (tables, spline points, scripts), and how reusable is the system across levels?
How do you iterate on cutscenes with music—do you measure BPM, or is it all by ear and frame nudges?

open_questions.context: The Western course includes a small town plus a surreal canyon area with oversized props, a scavenger-hunt mission, and optional warp-pipe shortcuts.
questions: What are the planned stars for the Western level (beyond the scavenger hunt), and how many will be town-focused vs canyon-focused?
How do you prevent the canyon area from feeling like ‘random geometry’ once enemies, coins, and objectives are added?
Will the train be interactive (rideable/moving), or primarily a set piece?

open_questions.topic: Accessibility: color-coded pipes and colorblind play
open_questions.context: Kaze chooses color differentiation (and tweaks red/orange separation) but rejects adding symbols/text labels, arguing mis-entry cost is low.
questions: Did you test pipe readability with any colorblind players or use simulators formally?
Would you consider non-color cues (shape/trim patterns) if later playtests show confusion?
How often do players need to use the shortcuts for optimal routes (speedruns vs casual)?

open_questions.topic: GeoASM pipe-color system and crash root cause
open_questions.context: Crash traced to Kaze’s “geo set pipe color” code; he used NEMU64 to get PC address and debug without symbols.
questions: What was the exact bug in the geo set pipe color routine, and what guardrails did you add to prevent similar crashes?
How do behavior parameters (bparam2, etc.) map to render state changes in your architecture?
Do you have automated tests or debug builds to catch these earlier?

open_questions.topic: Asset workflow reliability (lost textures, packing resources)
open_questions.context: Kaze repeatedly ‘lost the texture again’ and relies on Blender resource packing and occasionally borrowing community textures.
questions: Why do textures/resources go missing in your pipeline—version control, Blender packing, or export steps?
What changes did you make (if any) to ensure asset reproducibility across machines/team members?
How do you manage a shared asset library with contributors like Pyro J/PowerJay?

open_questions.context: Kaze insists on staying within 64MB and frames larger carts as ‘cheating,’ despite technical possibility.
questions: What’s the current ROM size budget breakdown (textures, music, geometry, code) and biggest risks to staying under 64MB?
Have you had to cut/redo content specifically due to size constraints?
Is the 64MB rule purely philosophical/authenticity-driven, or tied to specific hardware goals (flash carts, repro carts)?

open_questions.topic: Open-source release plans under Nintendo constraints
open_questions.context: Kaze says the game will be open source and cannot be monetized, implying legal risk management as a core release constraint.
questions: What exact license and distribution model are you planning (source only, patch-only, assets separated)?
How do you protect collaborators (music/art) in an open-source repo while keeping the project shareable?
What’s your plan if Nintendo issues a takedown—mirrors, forks, or separating code from assets?

open_questions.context: Kaze states Biobak will finish specific level areas; Zeina is making a key skull prop; music needs remain for unfinished sections.
questions: How do you coordinate work with Biobak/Zeina/Badub day-to-day (issues list, Discord, milestones)?
What content blocks Kaze from finishing a level (art, collision, music, scripting), and how do you schedule around those dependencies?
Which parts of levels does Kaze prefer to keep personally vs delegate?

open_questions.topic: Testing strategy: emulator vs real hardware
open_questions.context: Kaze uses PJ64 for quick checks, NEMU64 for debugging, and emphasizes emulators mainly to approximate real N64 output; he prefers real hardware for accuracy.
questions: What’s your standard QA loop: emulator build frequency vs flashcart/hardware tests?
Which classes of bugs only show up on real N64 for your project (timing, RDP quirks, memory)?
Do you maintain multiple emulator profiles for performance/accuracy checks?
